awd_titl_txt: Fast algorithms for nonlinear kinetic models
awd_abstract_narration:
In multiscale modeling hierarchy, the Boltzmann and related kinetic equations serve as a building block that bridges atomistic and continuum models. These equations describe the non-equilibrium dynamics of a gas or system comprised of a large number of particles in random motion and constantly colliding with each other, and have found applications in various fields such as rarefied gas/plasma dynamics, radiative transfer, semiconductor modeling, etc. The prominent challenges associated with numerically approximating the Boltzmann-like equations are the expense of evaluating the collision term - a high-dimensional, nonlinear, nonlocal integral operator. Fast algorithms developed in this project will greatly advance the state-of-the-art simulation of collisional kinetic equations, and will enable scientists and engineers to effectively handle more complex systems that have previously not been feasible, due to the enormous expense of evaluating the collision term.

The new algorithms will be based on spectral approximation which stands out for its superior accuracy among the available Boltzmann solvers. To reduce the huge computational cost of conventional spectral methods, the main idea is to exploit and leverage the convolutional and low-rank structure in the collision integral. Four specific aims will be addressed: 1) fast algorithms for the Boltzmann collision operator with general collision kernel that will allow efficient simulation of particle interactions beyond hard sphere model; 2) fast algorithms for the multi-species Boltzmann equation, which would be invaluable for describing gaseous mixtures; 3)fast algorithms for the inelastic Boltzmann equation, which have immediate application in modeling granular materials; 4) a fast deterministic solver for the Schrodinger-quantum Boltzmann system modeling the kinetics of Bose-Einstein condensate at finite temperature.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past four years, we have completed the major goal of this project: development of generic fast Fourier spectral methods for a class of nonlinear collisional kinetic models. This includes the Boltzmann equation with general collision kernels; the multi-species Boltzmann equation; the inelastic Boltzmann equation; and recently the non-cutoff Boltzmann equation. 

Due to the high-dimensionality and complexity of these kinetic equations, the particle based direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method is dominantly employed in many science and engineering applications. However, the method suffers from slow convergence and severe statistical noise especially for unsteady and low speed flows. Now with the advance of the fast algorithms developed under this project, we are able to construct highly accurate and efficient deterministic methods for solving the multi-dimensional Boltzmann equation. This was previously unfeasible due to the excessive cost of evaluating the collision operator. The new method, which we coined as DGFS, couples the discontinuous Galerkin (DG) method in the physical space and fast Fourier spectral (FS) method in the velocity space, has been validated on many benchmark tests of rarefied flows. For example, the figure on the right shows a comparison of DGFS and DSMC in a 2D thermally driven cavity flow. Due to the low speed, the DSMC results contain excessive noise while DGFS can provide quite accurate results using moderate discretization parameters.

Algorithm-wise, we believe that the proposed method that exploits the low-rank and convolutional structure in the collisional integral provides a general mathematical framework to accelerate the Fourier-Galerkin spectral method. Similar idea might also be applicable to other spectral methods using polynomial basis, hence opens the door for future research.
